docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 22 -- Uruguay passed her second quiet day since President Alfredo Baldomir carried out his coup d'etat yesterday by dissolving Congress and taking all State powers into his own hands.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 22 -- Uruguay passed her second quiet day since President Alfredo Baldomir carried out his coup d'etat yesterday by dissolving Congress and taking all State powers into his own hands.
docs.abstract: Baldomir creates State Council; Herrera reptd planning to live in exile; ban on Charlone in event of Pres vacancy indicated; Army Staff Chief Gen P Sicco resigns; 2 Herrerista Deputies, held for defying police, freed

headline.main: URUGUAY TO GET RULE BY A COUNCIL; Baldomir Creates Body to Act in Place of the Congress He Dissolved Saturday COUNTRY REMAINS QUIET Government Is Not Expected to Be Able to Have Vote on Its Reforms for Months

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Battleship Admiral Graf Spee: 2 crew members caught in escape attempt; jailed, Uruguay

headline.main: GRAF SPEE MEN CAUGHT; Two Fail in Swim to Spanish Ship in Montevideo Harbor

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 23 -- Police intervened and prevented a street clash today between opponents and supporters of President Alfredo Baldomir, who spent the day on the reorganizing of the government following his dissolution of Congress on...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 23 -- Police intervened and prevented a street clash today between opponents and supporters of President Alfredo Baldomir, who spent the day on the reorganizing of the government following his dissolution of Congress on Saturday to avert what he declared were threats of a pro-Axis revolt.
docs.abstract: police avert riot, Montevideo; Baldomir has difficulty in forming councils; backed by press; Herrera to stay in Uruguay

headline.main: URUGUAYAN POLICE AVERT STREET RIOT; Pro-Baldomir Crowd Prevented From Attacking Opponents -- Press Backs President HERRERA STAYS TO FIGHT Montevideo Situation Points to Hitch in Forming a Council to Replace the Congress

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 25 -- Strict measures are being taken by the Argentine Government to prevent Buenos Aires from becoming a refuge for Axis diplomats oblige to leave other Latin-American countries as a result of rupture in relations...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 25 -- Strict measures are being taken by the Argentine Government to prevent Buenos Aires from becoming a refuge for Axis diplomats oblige to leave other Latin-American countries as a result of rupture in relations following the Rio de Janeiro conference.
docs.abstract: to end handling of interests in Salvador

headline.main: Argentina Bans Envoys of Axis Ousted From Other Countries; Election Is to Be Held Sunday and Much Support From All Parties Is Seen for Anti-War Policy of Castillo

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 27 -- In a gesture that should go far toward strengthening the united American front, Chile energetically protested today against the sinkings by Axis submarines of ships belonging to Brazil and Venezuela.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 27 -- In a gesture that should go far toward strengthening the united American front, Chile energetically protested today against the sinkings by Axis submarines of ships belonging to Brazil and Venezuela.
docs.abstract: Chile cites 1917 protest against unrestricted submarine warfare

headline.main: CHILE WARNS AXIS ON U-BOAT ACTIONS; Protest on Sinkings of Ships of Brazil and Uruguay Delivered to Envoys 1917 SITUATION RECALLED Notes by Rossetti Emphasize Chilean 'Solidarity' With the Other American Nations

docs.snippet: Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Columbia School of Journalism, returned yesterday with Mrs. Ackerman from a tour of Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil, where he went last December to study South American newspapers under war conditions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Columbia School of Journalism, returned yesterday with Mrs. Ackerman from a tour of Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil, where he went last December to study South American newspapers under war conditions.
